case_name: Shersingh, Baljor and Vijaipal v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 191 of 1964 in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 191 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 20, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Government Appeal No. 1386 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated May 20, 1964 in Government Appeal No. 1386 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 20, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Government Appeal No. 1386 of 1962. S. R. Chari and A. K. Nag, for the appellants.

facts.text: Three appellants convicted by Allahabad High Court under section 302/34 IPC for murder of Harpal and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for life

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants have been companyvicted by the High Court of Allahabad under s. 302/34 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of one Harpal and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for life, after reversing their acquittal by the Sessions Judge, Meerut.

facts.text: High Court reversed acquittal by Sessions Judge Meerut

anchor.surface_text: ...for life, after reversing their acquittal by the Sessions Judge, Meerut. Originally five persons were tried for this offence. All of them were acquitted by the Sessions Court.

facts.text: Originally five persons tried for the offence, all acquitted by Sessions Court

anchor.surface_text: Originally five persons were tried for this offence. All of them were acquitted by the Sessions Court. On appeal, the acquittal of the other two  Shanker and Tarif  was maintained but the three appellants  Shersingh, Baljor and Vijaipal  were companyvicted.

facts.text: Acquittal of Shanker and Tarif maintained by High Court, three appellants Shersingh, Baljor and Vijaipal convicted

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the acquittal of the other two  Shanker and Tarif  was maintained but the three appellants  Shersingh, Baljor and Vijaipal  were companyvicted. They number appeal by special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Appellants are brothers and sons of Narayansingh

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are brothers and sons of Narayansingh. Tarif and Shanker are brothers of Narayansingh. The deceased Harpal was the brother of Naharsingh  P. W. 1  and Amichand W. 5 .

facts.text: Tarif and Shanker are brothers of Narayansingh

anchor.surface_text: Tarif and Shanker are brothers of Narayansingh. The deceased Harpal was the brother of Naharsingh  P. W. 1  and Amichand W. 5 . The house of Amichand and his brothers is in front of that of the appellants,

facts.text: Deceased Harpal was brother of Naharsingh PW1 and Amichand PW5

anchor.surface_text: The deceased Harpal was the brother of Naharsingh  P. W. 1  and Amichand W. 5 . The house of Amichand and his brothers is in front of that of the appellants, in Mauza Amanullahpur, Police Station Jani, District Meerut,

facts.text: Houses of Amichand and brothers in front of appellants' house in Mauza Amanullahpur, PS Jani, District Meerut

anchor.surface_text: The house of Amichand and his brothers is in front of that of the appellants, in Mauza Amanullahpur, Police Station Jani, District Meerut, where the offence was companymitted,

facts.text: Murder resulted from petty quarrel over taking carts through fields

anchor.surface_text: where the offence was companymitted, As frequently happens this murder was the result of a petty quarrel earlier over the taking of carts through fields.

facts.text: Shersingh took his cart through Harpal's field leading to wordy quarrel

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say that Shersingh took his cart through Harpals field and there was a wordy quarrel. Next Shersingh stopped a cart in which Harpal was carrying sugarcane and Harpal kicked Shersingh and beat him with fist blows.

facts.text: Shersingh stopped cart carrying sugarcane of Harpal, Harpal kicked and beat Shersingh with fists, separated by Nahar Singh PW1 and Khazan PW7

anchor.surface_text: Next Shersingh stopped a cart in which Harpal was carrying sugarcane and Harpal kicked Shersingh and beat him with fist blows. Nahar Singh  P. W. 1  and Khazan  P. W. 7  separated them. The murder followed close upon the heels of the second incident.

facts.text: On morning of November 26, 1961 at about 7 a.m. Harpal left his gher to answer call of nature

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution is that a fortnight later on the morning of November, 26, 1961 at about 7 a.m. Harpal left his ghair  companypound  to answer a call of nature.

facts.text: Near gate of his house, appellants Shersingh, Baljor, Vijaipal and two acquitted Shanker, Tarif attacked Harpal

anchor.surface_text: Near the gate of his house the appellants and the two accused  since acquitted  fell upon him. Sher Singh and Vijaipal had spears and Shanker and Baljor had lathis.

facts.text: Sher Singh and Vijaipal had spears, Shanker and Baljor had lathis, Tarif had stick but exhorted to kill without beating

anchor.surface_text: Sher Singh and Vijaipal had spears and Shanker and Baljor had lathis. They beat Harpal with their weapons. Tarif, who also had a stick, took numberpart in the beating but exhorted the others to kill Harpal.

facts.text: Harpal pierced in chest and abdomen with spears and struck with sticks

anchor.surface_text: Harpal was pierced in the chest and abdomen with spears and struck with sticks. On his shout for help his brothers Naharsingh and Amichand, who were working in the back portion of their house came running

facts.text: Eye-witnesses: Naharsingh PW1, Amichand PW5 came running; Bhupal PW2, Tara PW3, Katara PW4, Atarsingh (not examined)

anchor.surface_text: On his shout for help his brothers Naharsingh and Amichand, who were working in the back portion of their house came running and three or four witnesses Bhupal  P. W. 2 , Tara  P. W. 3 , Katara  P. W. 4  and one Atarsingh  who was number examined  came from different sides.

facts.text: Assailants fled, Harpal fallen down, lifted on cot, covered with quilt, but was dead

anchor.surface_text: The assailants then fled. Harpal who had fallen down was lifted, placed on a company and companyered with a quilt. He was however dead The autopsy later disclosed two penetrating wounds in his chest

facts.text: Autopsy: two penetrating wounds in chest each tearing heart, one penetrating transfixing stomach, some contusions

anchor.surface_text: He was however dead The autopsy later disclosed two penetrating wounds in his chest each of which had torn through his heart, a penetrating wound transfixing the stomach and some companytusions. He must have died in a matter of minutes.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted all five accused after exhaustive discussion of evidence

anchor.surface_text: The five accused were tried for his murder but were acquitted. On appeal the three appellants were companyvicted and sentenced. The learned Sessions Judge in a long judgment exhaustively discussed the evidence but lost himself in the details of family relationship

facts.text: High Court reappraised evidence, convicted three appellants, acquitted Shanker and Tarif giving benefit of doubt

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a reappraisal of the evidence came to a companytrary companyclusion although it maintained the acquittal of Shanker and Tarif by giving them the benefit of the doubt.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds eye-witness testimony consistent, convincing and credible, accepts High Court findings

anchor.surface_text: We have had the evidence of the eye-witnesses read to us and after careful companysideration we are satisfied that it is companysistent, companyvincing and credible. ... We accept the findings of the High Court which are supported by evidence of sufficient probative force to satisfy us.

facts.text: No blood found at spot, explained by sandy ground and internal bleeding

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari sought to strengthen this argument from the circumstance that numberblood was found at the spot, or in the tidri where the company was spread or on the clothes. The Sub- Inspector Chauhal  P. W. 10  said that the place of the attack was sandy and blood had probably been trampled upon.

facts.text: Petitioner contends medical evidence contradicts oral testimony on position of victim

anchor.surface_text: Chari said that the description of the injuries shows that Harpal must be lying down and number standing when the first and second blows were given because one stab was downwards and the upwards. , This is number companyclusive.

issues.text: Whether the powers of the High Court in an appeal from an acquittal are in no way different from those in an appeal from a conviction

anchor.surface_text: It has been pointed out before by this Court as also the Judicial Committee that the powers of the High Court in an appeal from an acquittal are in no way different from those in an appeal from a conviction. The High Court can consider the evidence and weigh the probabilities.

issues.text: Whether the evidence showed that the attack must have taken place elsewhere

anchor.surface_text: His argument was that the High Court ought to have seen that the medical evidence contradicted the oral testimony, the evidence clearly showed that the attack must have taken place elsewhere and that the eye-witnesses were interested in the victim and hostile to the accused.

arguments.claim: High Court can consider the evidence and weigh the probabilities; accept/reject evidence unless demeanour relied on; must address acquittal grounds considering presumption

anchor.surface_text: The High Court can consider the evidence and weigh the probabilities. It can accept evidence rejected by the Sessions Judge and reject evidence accepted by him, unless the Sessions Judge relied upon his observation of the demeanour of a particular witness.

anchor.surface_text: It can accept evidence rejected by the Sessions Judge and reject evidence accepted by him, unless the Sessions Judge relied upon his observation of the demeanour of a particular witness.
